content:
✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Works
The Goal could be written better, though

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Tested and validated with a solution in Python.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: All tests and validators are ok with language Kotlin solution

❌ Rejected the contribution.
Comment: test cases includes not only alphabetical character. Maybe you should specify to ignore them

The phrasing is a little weird(I wouldn't call those a letter's "corresponding digit"), making it more clear that it's just adding up the place the letter is in the alphabet I think would improve the experience of people solving the problem.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: All tests and validators are ok with language C solution

❌ Rejected the contribution.
Comment: Given the fact that the contribution is currently containing errors, but on the brink of accidental approval, this contribution should be rejected before it accidentally enters the pool of live clashes.

❌ Rejected the contribution.
Comment: Wrong expected output in validators.

❌ Rejected the contribution.
Comment: Some tests / validators are wrong! For example Validator 1 should give 'x'

I feel like I am overlooking something, please help me out.
Validator 1: jviorjeio#@)(jJ309eh9H$#(8fh9hF#(*H3i))), only the letters are jviorjeiojJehHfhhFHi, which translate to the values 9, 21, 8, 14, 17, 9, 4, 8, 14, 9, 9, 4, 7, 7, 5, 7, 7, 5, 7, 8, which summed is 179, which %26 is 23, which is x --> but according to you it should be r. Where is my mistake?
My code: 
s = input()
abc = 'abcdefghijklmnopqrstuvwxyz'
out = 0
for x in s:
    if x.isalpha():
        out+=abc.index(x.lower())
print(abc[out%26])

In any case, tests and validators should be balanced: test1 is very easy, so validator1 should be equally easy. Best to let players bump into special characters only later on - and not put it in a validator while it is not in the same test.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Great job!
I found it to be a bit more difficult to implement than initially expected, but very fun. Great job!

Now I'm trying to implement my own solution and I have some difficulties.
I tried to compare my code with your code and the only difference was in line five. There you use "sum += char.indexOf(c)" but I think that it has to be "sum += char.indexOf(c.toLowerCase())". When I copy your solution and change the line, the code doesn't work anymore. 
Can you may explain why you did it like this? Or is this a bug?
Cool task! It's a nice mix of different commands that you can use every now and then.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Very creative and interesting for the new programmers !

Goal section
* Shouldn't it be "goes above 25", and 26=a, 27=b, etc?

* Please mention how any characters outside the alphabet should be treated (ignored?).

Input section
* It is better to use the term "digits" instead of "numbers" when referring to individual characters. The difference is not important in this clash, but it may be important to distinguish between the two terms in some other situations.

Output section
* Please change "An" to "A".

Solution code
* I think your solution code may fail if sum == 26.

Cases
* In view of the above comments, I would suggest you to add two more pairs of cases (i.e. 4 cases in total), one pair where the sum = 26, and another pair where the sum is a multiple of 26.

Thanks.

Me waiting for 5DN1L to come and help me fix my terribly written clash:
(ty a lot man
Sorry for taking a while.... I'm back now! I have fixed everything you mentioned, and realized my solution code was very flawed...
ty!
ty!
Oh! I think I see the problem. I will fix it asap. Ty!
ty!
Please do not approve a contribution when another person has pointed out an issue which has not been fixed yet. Thank you.

The solution code is wrong as pointed out in CodingFox28's comment below. So, the expected output is wrong too.

@Storm_Blackthorn Please fix the bug and the issues pointed out by jddingemanse. Thanks.
@Maths4life, did you write a solution code of your own to verify the cases? The expected output of some cases is wrong and the contribution shouldn't have been approved yet.
I've edited the statement and changed "alphabets" to "letters" (an alphabet is a set of letters).
